Package xxl.core.collections.bags

Contains some bags.

See:
          Description

Interface Summary
Bag<E> The interface bag represents a data type that is able to contain any kind of object and performs no duplicate detection.
FIFOBag<E> The interface FIFO bag represents a FIFO (first in, first out) iteration over the elements of a bag.
LIFOBag<E> The interface LIFO bag represents a LIFO (last in, first out) iteration over the elements of a bag.
 

Class Summary
AbstractBag<E> This class provides a skeletal implementation of the Bag interface, to minimize the effort required to implement this interface.
ArrayBag<E> This class provides an implementation of the Bag interface that internally uses an array with fixed size to store its elements.
ContainerBag This class provides an implementation of the Bag interface that internally uses a container to store its elements.
DecoratorBag<E> The class provides a decorator for a bag that follows the Decorator Design Pattern (for further details see Structural Patterns, Decorator in Design Patterns: Elements of Reusable Object-Oriented Software by Erich Gamma, Richard Helm, Ralph Johnson, and John Vlissides).
DynamicArrayBag This class provides an implementation of the Bag interface that internally uses a resizable array to store its elements.
EmptyBag This class provides an empty bag.
ListBag<E> This class provides an implementation of the Bag interface that internally uses a list to store its elements.
UnmodifiableBag This class provides a decorator for a given bag that cannot be modified.
 

Package xxl.core.collections.bags Description

Contains some bags. In contrast to the Java collections framework, any bag of this framework supports a close method. This methode releases any system resources associated with collection and is very important for collections using external resources like files or JDBC resources.
